description: From Anglo-Norman resigner, Middle French resigner, and its source, Latin resignāre (“to unseal, annul, assign, resign”), from re- + signāre (“to seal, stamp”).

verbs.description: resign (third-person singular simple present resigns, present participle resigning, simple past and past participle resigned)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To give up; to relinquish ownership of. [from 14th c.]
(transitive) To hand over (something to someone), place into the care or control of another.
(transitive or intransitive) To quit (a job or position). [from 14th c.]
examples: I am resigning in protest of the unfair treatment of our employees.
He resigned the crown to follow his heart.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To submit passively; to give up as hopeless or inevitable. [from 15th c.]
examples: He had no choice but to resign the game and let his opponent become the champion.

verbs.description: resign (third-person singular simple present resigns, present participle resigning, simple past and past participle resigned)

examples: Lastly, a note that I have resigned my GPG key to extend the expiration date.
